body:
@ijuma not really sure how you want me to test this.

I mean if we really wanted to, I guess I can unit test the GroupCoordinator constructor by instantiating a GroupCoordinator with a custom KafkaConfig.offsetsTopicCompressionCodec defined and verify that groupCoordinator.offsetConfig.offsetsTopicCompressionCodec has picked up the modification? Testing constructors seems kinda lame though.
LGTM.
Review by @gwenshap and @granthenke.
@becketqin @ijuma I updated this PR to limit the change to the new consumer only as @ijuma suggested. I would appreciate your feedback.
Should we add a comment to the README too? We have been doing that for most newly added tasks in the past.
Good suggestion @granthenke. I also renamed the task to `aggregatedJavadoc` as I think it explains the task better. We use the `All` suffix for tasks that are executed for multiple Scala versions.

Hi @ijuma I have created jira : https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3720 to handle the issue you mentioned. Once this goes in I will submit a PR for that. Let me know if any other changes are needed in this PR.
Thank you @MayureshGharat, LGTM.
Merged to trunk.
Do we need a documentation update?
We should also start a branchbuilder to make sure the upgrade tests didn't break
From a brief look, it seems fine apart from one comment (and one question for Jun). It would be good for @junrao to take a look too. And we definitely need to run the system tests.

Branch-builder test passed with 1 failed, confirmed as unrelated by @ewencp and @hachikuji.

+1 and merging to trunk and 0.10.0 branch

Thanks for the patch. A couple of comments.
1. We actually made another inter-broker protocol change related to SaslHandshake after the rack-awareness change. The following is how we are using it in KafkaConfig.
   
   val saslInterBrokerHandshakeRequestEnable = interBrokerProtocolVersion >= KAFKA_0_10_0_IV0

So, if we want to do this right, we will need to add 0.10.0-IV2 for SaslHandshake change and use 0.10.0-IV2 in KafkaConfig.
1. It's a bit hard to see which internal version is for which inter-broker protocol change. Could you add a comment for all the 0.10.0-IV\* to describe the corresponding protocol change?

I had an issue with the merge script, so cherry-picked manually to 0.10.0:
https://git-wip-us.apache.org/repos/asf?p=kafka.git;a=shortlog;h=refs/heads/0.10.0
@junrao since we are doing this at the wrong time, is there any benefit to adding two versions? People could be at any point in trunk at this point after all.
Upgrade tests running: https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/452/console

@ijuma : Yes, you are right. It's a bit too late to fix this completely at this moment. What we can probably do is to just change the reference to KAFKA_0_10_0_IV0 in KafkaConfig to KAFKA_0_10_0_IV1. This means that KAFKA_0_10_0_IV1 will be corresponding to both the rack-awareness and the SaslHandshake change.
Sounds good to me.

Thanks @junrao . I updated the patch to point SASL handshake to 0.10.0-IV1 as well.
@gwenshap I just submitted a new branch builder test. Should we stop the current branch builder test?
Thanks @becketqin - I stopped mine and let yours run.

killing the system test was a REALLY bad idea.
Looks like the test nodes are now in a bad state and won't run. I'm hoping @granders is around and can help.
Retrying, just in case.... https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/454/console
actually... https://jenkins.confluent.io/job/system-test-kafka-branch-builder/455/console
looking better now :)
Thanks, @gwenshap
Thanks for the patch. LGTM

@gwenshap noticed that the task didn't work with Java 8. The issue was that the code that makes javadoc 8 more lenient had to be moved to from `subprojects` to `allprojects`. Tested with Java 7 and 8 and they both worked on my laptop.
There were two system test failures in connect in the test run above and both look like unrelated intermittent test failures. @hachikuji @ewencp @ijuma Can you review this PR? Thank you.

I actually prefer the original `javadocAll` over `aggregatedJavadoc` just because it is consistent with other `xxAll` commands.

EDIT: Actually, my understanding of `javadoc` vs. `aggregatedJavadoc` may be wrong, so hold on that.
LGTM.
Merged to trunk.
LGTM. Just a nit comment on the original `javadoc` command.

@omkreddy I think the default compression.type (target codec) is "producer", meaning it adopts whatever the codec of the MessageSet was coming in. So it seems that updating the property in `GroupCoordinator. offsetsTopicConfigs` isn't really required. Thoughts?

Pinging @hachikuji for review.

@hachikuji doesn't this commit already contain the fetch manager metrics? https://github.com/coughman/kafka/commit/8c6ef282dddd68315d735f34d87fd93e21b50309
I'll update the section header to be "fetch manager"
LGTM
Checked with Guozhang and he's happy with the comment update. Merging to trunk and 0.10.0.
@ewencp Discovered when writing doc.

@Ishiihara This raises a related question as well which @hachikuji might also have an opinion on -- if an exception is thrown from a callback like this, should we set the status to FAILED and stop processing entirely?

For the immediate issue, this LGTM
@Ishiihara Actually, come to think of it, should both of these be accompanied by unit tests in `WorkerSourceTaskTest`?
cc @ewencp for review

@onurkaraman Good find. I guess the only difference if we set `compression.type` is how we'd react to a future config change. For example, if we initially set `offsets.topic.compression.codec` to snappy and write that to Zk as the topic's `compression.type`, then if we later change `offsets.topic.compression.codec` to gzip, we'd first compress as gzip and then recompress as snappy on writing (unless we change the code to alter the topic configuration). Alternatively, with the change as it is, we'll leave the data compressed according to whatever the current configuration is. That seems preferable to me.

But actually I'm a little confused. Isn't the `compression.type` for this topic explicitly set to `uncompressed` on that line above that @omkreddy points to above? Wouldn't that mean that we'd decompress before writing even with this patch? Seems like we actually need to change that to "producer." Maybe I'm missing something?

What is the issue that you're having with the current approach. Can you not return the received `KafkaPrincipal.ANONYMOUS` for the PLAINTEXT case (which is what `DefaultPrincipalBuilder` would do)? It seems more regular to me that the `principal.builder.class` is always used (it's a not ideal that we don't use it for SASL too).

Yeah my bad. My previous comment wasn't right. Unless the config is overridden, `compression.type` is `producer`. But we explicitly set the `compression.type` for the `__consumer_offsets` topic in [the line @omkreddy stated](https://github.com/onurkaraman/kafka/blob/d65726de2e4a196837de7bb2e11f397482826dca/core/src/main/scala/kafka/coordinator/GroupCoordinator.scala#L68).

It looks like `compression.type` can only be configured on a per-topic level during topic creation through `AdminUtils.createTopic` or through  dynamic config with `kafka-configs.sh`. I had been doing dynamic config.

I force pushed an update that explicitly sets the `compression.type` to `producer` so that the target codec always just adopts the source codec.

This seems better than removing the property altogether since that would make the target codec whatever the `compression.type` is at the time, which may not be `producer`. It would probably be surprising to set offsetsTopicCompressionCodec only to see the final target codec be something else.

@onurkaraman, with regards to testing, I think it might be useful to have an integration test where we configure the offsets topic to be compressed and then we verify that the topic is compressed with the expected compression algorithm.
LGTM

At the moment, you can override the principal for PLAINTEXT, for instance, set principal based on IP. Or set a different principal for PLAINTEXT from an unauthenticated SSL client. Feels like a useful config even for PLAINTEXT.
Review by @junrao
@ewencp would be great if you could take a look at this!
Thanks for the review @harshach, merging it to trunk and 0.10.0.

@miguno I mean "running ./gradlew test" passed on my local machine.

Did not add any unit tests in this PR since I realize they are already covered in other non-streams unit tests, so do not want to add overlaps. Previously we are not having any cases that would trigger 1) and 2) above, but I just add those validations for better exception messages.
@shikhar Thanks, LGTM!

@ijuma @rajinisivaram 
For PlainText we don't supply any PrincipalBuilder. For SSL we want to supply a principalBuilder using the property "principal.builder.class". 
1) Now consider we have a broker running on these 2 ports and supply that custom principalBuilder class using that config. 
2) The interbroker communication is using PlainText. I am using a single broker cluster for testing.
3) Now we issue a produce request on the SSL port of the broker. 
4) The controller tries to build a channel for plaintext with this broker for the new topic instructions.
5) PlainText tries to use the principal builder specified in the "principal.builder.class" config which was meant only for SSL port since the code path is same "ChannelBuilders.createPrincipalBuilder(configs)". 
6) In the custom principal Builder if we are trying to do some cert checks or down conversion of transportLayer to SSLTransportLayer so that we can use its functionality we get runtime exception.

The basic idea is the PlainText channel should not be using the PrincipalBuilder meant for other types of channels. We should probably have separate builders and authorizers for each type of channel if there is a valid use case here. For my usecase having a DefaultPrincipalBuilder for PlainText would suffice. But now that I think more, having a clear separation for those configs might be a good idea as a broker can run on multiple types of ports in future. 
I would be happy to start this discussion in Opensource email list and implement the patch if you guys agree.

@MayureshGharat Isn't the code in your custom principal builder in the method `buildPrincipal(TransportLayer transportLayer, Authenticator authenticator)`? If it is, you could simply check the type of `transportLayer` and have different code paths for PLAINTEXT and SSL. At the moment, you would need check if `transportLayer` is an instance of PlaintextTransportLayer or SslTransportLayer. It may be neater to add a method to return security protocol from `TransportLayer`.

@rajinisivaram Yeah right now I can have an "instanceOf" check or catch the downcasting exception and do the handling. Having a method in TransportLayer to return the type might be a good idea. But as the type of ports increase it means adding more checks to buildPrincipal right? Isn't it better to have separate configs for them instead? What do you think? That will be more cleaner IMO, though it increases the 2 configs (Authorizer and PrincipalBuilderClass) for each port type.

@MayureshGharat Personally I prefer smaller number of configs, especially since it can be made to work. But I do see your point about separate configs being neater. It will be good to see what others think.
I am personally in favour of less configs too. It may make sense to pass the security protocol as a parameter to `buildPrincipal` to make it clearer that this is something that needs to be handled.
LGTM. An integration test case would be nice if it's not too much trouble. Maybe we could commit an offset and then read it back using the simple consumer and verify that the right codec was used?

@ijuma I think we have 4 options from the above discussions. 
1) Doing instanceOf check.
2) TransportLayer should expose api for telling the protocol.
3) buildPrincipal() should take in a new param for the type of protocol and document this in the javadoc on how to use it?
4) Add extra configs for each type of channel.
Should I start a discussion on mailing list for this or do we agree on one of this? 
I am +1 for 3) and 4)

@oleksiyk please refer to [approach suggested](https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/KIP-35+-+Retrieving+protocol+version#KIP-35-Retrievingprotocolversion-Aclientdeveloperwantstoaddsupportforanewfeature) on KIP-35.

@hachikuji In the meantime I'm trying to run a successful build, I managed to add two unit tests to verify the impact of the change when auto commit is enabled or disabled. Hopefully they are close to what you expected.
@ijuma I force pushed an update that adds an integration test checking that the offsetsTopicCompressionCodec has been propagated.

Thanks for the PR. Can you please explain how this helps? It seems to me that one always needs to provide additional configuration when using a security protocol that is not PLAINTEXT, so it seems easy enough to set the security protocol in the same config. But I may be missing something.

Hi,
When I was working with Kerberos mechanisim, the only parameter setting needed is security-protocol to SASL_PLAINTEXT. I thought it will be helpful for the customers using Kerberos only. As you have said, for others, some additional parameters are needed.
@Ishiihara Seems better to me to let the exception propagate and the task fail. If we catch the exception, wouldn't we need to do some kind of rollback or retry?
@hachikuji This is invoked in a producer callback. Is that going to propagate? I thought the producer catches exceptions, logs them, and then ignores them.
@ewencp Ah, you're right. Logging is better than nothing I guess, but still seems kind of disturbing to ignore a commit failure, right? Maybe we should open a JIRA?

Yeah, @hachikuji as I mentioned in the original reply, we might want to propagate somehow, but that is definitely a bit more complicated of a patch. This really just addresses the short term issue by logging something more meaningful to Connect than the error you'd get from the producer callback exception handling.

Filed https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-3734 to follow up.
@ewencp Sounds like a plan. In that case, this change LGTM.

@gwenshap thanks for the review.

Below are the goals.
- Allow clients to not utilize KIP-35.
- Allow clients interested in KIP-35 to be able to check if all api versions it needs is supported by a broker.
- Api version check has to be done for each new connection, even for re-connects.

Below is the design overview.
- For each new connection established, if client, i.e., `KafkaProducer`/ `KafkaConsumer`, has specified api versions it will be using, send `ApiVersions` request.
- When `ApiVersions` response is received, client validates that client's requested api versions are supported by broker. If not, throw `KafkaException`.
- Whether a connection is ready to send requests is determined as below.
  - If client does not want to check api versions, i.e, client has not specified required api versions, the connection must be in `CONNECTED` state.
  - If client wants to check api versions, i.e., client has specified required api versions, the connection must be in `READY` state.

Valid connection states transitions.
- Client does not want to perform api versions check. Note that this is what it is right now.
  `DISCONNECTED` ->  `CONNECTING` -> `CONNECTED`
- Client wants to perform api versions check. Added with this patch.
  `DISCONNECTED` ->  `CONNECTING` -> `CONNECTED` -> `CHECKING_API_VERSIONS` -> `READY`

> Mind explaining why you chose to plug in the validation where you did? 
> Both why do you think a new state is needed and why do you think handleConnection() (which until now just did some metrics) is the correct place for the validation?

A new state is needed as a connection can be ready to send requests on either in `CONNECTED` or in `READY` state, based on client's need to check api versions.

As the api versions check is done for each connection, it is best to do it when we have a connection established. If check passes transition it to `READY` state that indicates successful api versions check. If the check fails, the connection is closed and an `KafkaException` is thrown.

> It looks like you are validation every response. But - brokers can't respond in anything other than the request version, which the client provides.
> I thought we discussed only validating the broker APIs when connecting. What made you change your mind?

I don't think every response is getting validated, only `ApiVersion` response will be validated. `ApiVersion` request is only sent while connecting.
Closed this pull request due to issues in this branch. Opened new Pull request #1409 for this.

Found two potential memory leaks: `RocksDBStore.pullAllInternal()` has the `WriteBatch` not disposed; and `KStreamKStreamJoin` creating new `RocksDBKeyValueIterator` but not closing it.

Ping @norwood @theduderog @gwenshap @enothereska for reviews.
LGTM.  Thanks @guozhangwang

Thanks for the PR, left a couple of comments, the rest looks good. I think we should file a JIRA to write a system test that detects memory leaks as it seems a bit easy to do with RocksDB and the consequences are pretty bad.

@enothereska, do you want to check the PR as well?
@MayureshGharat @ijuma Isn't 3) a breaking change of a public interface? I imagine 3) and 4) need a KIP since they change externals.
Ok, checked above as well as RockDB iterators and whether we're disposing of them. LGTM.
@ewencp mind giving it another look?
@ijuma I would like to add the system test, is there some examples from other modules that I can take a look? anyways, filing a JIRA first.
@guozhangwang I don't think we have any system tests for memory leaks yet. It will probably require some investigation on what's the best way to do it.
@ijuma Sounds good. Will start a mailing list discussion on this.
@ijuma Could you take another look?

Updated the code so that user can give security-protocol option through config file / security-protocol option. Added a null check if it is not updated through configuration file, then take default/user provided through option. If user has given through security-protocol option also it will work fine, as the property will not be there it will return null and update the security.protcol to user value/default value.
LGTM, thanks.
Merged to trunk.
Thanks @MayureshGharat. During the the request timeout KIP, was there a discussion about a metric to replace the buffer exhausted one?
cc @junrao

@ijuma I don't think the KIP-19 had any discussion about that. Since now we are failing a request if there is not enough memory by default, its the same behavior as BufferExhaustException and we probably should add another metric for this I think to replace the old one.
LGTM

Since this is just a doc fix, I pushed it to both trunk and 0.10.0. Thanks for the PR @harshach.

Quick note: there is a typo in the PR title (specifiy -> specify) and since there is no JIRA, the PR title should be prefixed with "MINOR: ". I fixed it in the merged commit, but it would be good to fix it here as well.

@ijuma sorry for not responding earlier, somehow I missed the email notification.

I was testing with a repo which had diverged from trunk and had some other fixes. The NPE does not seem to occur with the current code in trunk since the channel to the offset manager is opened first where it specifically requests for a PLAINTEXT endpoint  - [link](https://github.com/arunmahadevan/kafka/blob/3c337295ed6938206e6891732f2da85b581fdc30/core/src/main/scala/kafka/client/ClientUtils.scala#L115). It then exits with a message "Error while executing consumer group command End point PLAINTEXT not found for broker 0". The method `getZkConsumer` does not get invoked at all.

To test this I ran the below command after enabling kerberos with SASL_PLAINTEXT listener.
`bin/kafka-consumer-groups.sh --zookeeper hostname:2181  --describe --group test-consumer-group  --command-config config/consumer.properties`.

The proposed patch fixes getZkConsumer to read the endpoint info correctly which could potentially cause NPE if invoked from a different context in future, but right now there is no NPE since the code that invokes this method fails fast.
